author: SetTrend
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

After I entered `git status`, `exit` doesn't exit PowerShell 7.1.4.

### Expected behavior

PowerShell should exit

### Actual behavior

PowerShell won't exit

### Environment data

```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
### Visuals

![PowerShell won't exit](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/130369635-ad05a060-d4ec-4b1d-969a-c92a50c90663.gif)

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
What happens when you run `$host.SetShouldExit(0)`? What's the output of `Get-Command git`?

Completely off topic, what's the screen recording tool you used? I like the fade in/out transitions.

comments.author: SetTrend
comments.body:
Thank you for your nice comment.

In fact, `$host.SetShouldExit(0)` behaves the same as `exit`:

![PowerShell won't exit - 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/130482096-c3cf678e-416d-4a17-abd9-fa0bde0866a0.gif)

Also, see above screencast for the output of `Get-Command git`.

I'm using Camtasia by TechSmith for all my screencasts:

![Techsmith Camtasia](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/130482063-a363e623-abbd-4b0a-983c-397c2c4a4a2a.png)

It comes with a recorder and very nifty tools for adding animations, annotations, visual focus etc. to the recording. It's very easy to use. In fact, it's a WPF program, utilizing all the [`Visual`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.windows.media.visual) power of WPF.

Usually, I'm adding an animation to the beginning and end of the screencast (the yellow arrow in the screenshot) turning down opacity of the clip at either end.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: Hmm the `git` command is definitely the executable and not some custom function that might be messing with the Runspace stack so I'm unsure as to why `exit`/`$host.SetShouldExit` is not doing anything. If you use a tool like process explorer do you find powershell is being run in another shell and/or that `exit` closes at least one process when run?

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: So I've seen behaviour like this before: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/11542. Possible that that's what's happening here?

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
Does this only happen if the last command before the exit was git ? 

I've got an open issue with notebooks https://github.com/dotnet/interactive/issues/1546#issuecomment-904871225 
where something fails to detect that git has finished executing.

comments.author: SetTrend
comments.body:
I tested different commands now, and it seems it's actually just the `git status` command that's keeping PowerShell from closing.

Actually, hitting <kbd>CTRL</kbd>+<kbd>C</kbd> then eventually closes the PowerShell window.

comments.author: SetTrend
comments.body: Maybe this is rather a `git` issue than a PowerShell issue ..?

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: Probably the best thing to do at this point is to attach a debugger and work out what `exit` is waiting on. Unfortunately I can't reproduce this issue on my own Windows machine. Are you maybe sitting in quite a large git repo?

comments.author: SetTrend
comments.body:
The `git` repository suggested to update `git` to the latest version. Apparently, the previous version had an issue.

Updating `git` to the latest version fixed the problem.

Thanks for all of you for taking your valuable time here!

title: `exit` doesn't exit PowerShell
